column2: das Neves, Débora David. 2004/2005. Processo Morfofonológicos em Suruí do Tocantins. Anais da XX Jornada GELNE.

This article is from a chapter of das Neves 2000's dissertation Língua Suruí do Tocantins: Uma Introdução à Morfossintaxe; we couldn't access the original source so this article is coded instead. das Neves proposes two morphophonological processes: (1) rightward LDNH, triggered by the word-final nasal in a root (p. 626), which spreads and nasalizes root initial or medial [p] of the following root or suffix. This process is blocked if the root that contains [p] also contains a nasal consonant in the morpheme (p. 626). Vowels of the root that undergoes this process are transparent and do not nasalize; (2) rightward MPP, triggered by the causative prefix {mu}, nasalizes adjacent roots beginning with [t] (p. 627). das Neves only proposes underlying /N/ for Suruí do Tocantins.

Suruí do Tocatins [ISO: mdz] is a separate language from Surui spoken in Rondônia [ISO: sru-ro].   No phonemic table is provided; natural classes are coded from data and could contain errors or not completely reflect the phonemes and allophones of Suruí do Tocantins.

Word-final or root-final nasal consonant nasalizes /p/ in initial or medial position of following word or suffix (ex. koŋ # puku → koŋ muku); blocked if a nasal consonants is part of the undergoing morpheme.

column7: Lexically-conditioned roots and suffixes with initial or medial /p/

column4: V, t, k, ʔ, ɡ, ɾ, w, j

column2: If the preceding morpheme contains a nasal consonant, it will nasalize following root-initial /t/ in lexically specified roots

Lopes, Jorge D. 2014. Uma interface da documentação linguística e modelos lexicográficos para línguas indígenas brasileiras: uma proposta para o Suruí-Aikewára. Brasília, Brasil. Universidade de Brasília:dissertation.

Paper is a proposal of lexicography and orthography for Suruí do Tocantins. Lopes cites Monserrat (1985-86), Barbosa (1993), and Graham (1988) for certain phonemes and allophones, as well as explanation for nasal harmony processes in Suruí but does not propose their own analysis. Lopes notes that Suruí has lost contrastive nasal vowels, like Asuriní do Tocantins and Guajajára/Tembé. The prefix /mɔ/, which previously triggered the nasalization of roots with voiceless obstruents, no longer triggers that nasalization (p. 79).
[j] as an allophone of /s/ is cited from from Barbosa (1993). Notes that this dissertation does not consider nasal vowels to exist in Suruí do Tocantins (p. 78).
